concept.title: Our friend the tree
concept.shortdesc: Remind yourself few basic facts about trees. Learn the difference between heartwood, sapwood, and ripening wood. Here you will learn what you have still did not know or remember what you have already forgotten about our friend the tree.

conbody.p: Trees aren't just wood; they're, like everything from Mother Nature, a masterpiece. A complicated system guarantees the long life of the largest organisms on earth. A tree consists of roots, trunk, and leafy crown, each species has its special characteristics. These characteristics can differ from the norm due to external conditions and show the enormous flexibility of the woody plant. Bizarre shapes occasionally arise and touch our hearts and eyes. We take out the magnifying glass and take a closer look at the marvel.

section.title: This is how the tree distributes its tasks

table.title: Optical division of the tree shows the various function:

row.entry: The roots absorb water and nutrients and act as anchoring in the ground.

entry.p: The tree trunk connects the roots with the branches and leaves and ensures an exchange of the required substances.

row.entry: The leaves absorb the energy of the sun and carry out photosynthesis.

section.title: It should be big and strong
section.p: A seed sprouts and over time a stem develops from the shoot. This not only grows in height but also in width. This is because the location of the so-called cambium is directly under the bark. A layer that forms new wood cells during the growth period and not only inwards: the young cells also supply the outer bark for reinforcement and the cambium grows with increasing thickness.

section.title: One ring at a time

image.alt: tree trunk cross section annual rings

section.p: The cells do not grow equally all year round. Every year in spring, leaves need a lot of water and nutrients to emerge. For this purpose, spacious and thin-walled cells of lighter color are produced, the earlywood. From late summer the cambium switches to narrow, thick-walled, and the darker cells of the latewood are on the program. Voila, a beautiful pattern has emerged, the shape of the annual rings.

section.title: Sapwood, heartwood or ripening wood?
section.p: Sapwood is the younger and mostly light-colored wood in the outer annual rings. In some tree species, the inner sapwood becomes cored. The heartwood stores substances such as , wax, fats, and , and thus becomes more resistant, harder, and darker. If there is without , one speaks of a ripening wood. There are also tree species such as the elm, in which we can find all three kinds. We can call it the core ripening wood.

section.title: Firmly anchored
section.p: If a tree had no roots, it wouldn't be able to survive. Not only would it tip over, but the entire supply would also be impossible. Depending on the nature of the soil and the type of tree, we can roughly divide the root system into three systems:

ul.li: Shallow roots - after the main root has died off, the attach their vertical side shoots to the base of the shoot; the result is a flat but large root plate.
Heart Roots - with the rhizome as the base, there are many main vertical ; there are numerous root branches that radiate vertically or diagonally from it.
Taproots - here the roots run very deep into the ground like a pole as a direct extension of the trunk.

section.p: But no matter what type of root, each one enters into a symbiosis with mushrooms to bring the water on its way up. Just like us humans, the trees are hardly able to survive on their own and detached from the creatures around them. The health of the forest is also based on constant give and take. The balance creates a pleasant climate and good community. This is no different in the forest than in the city.
